questions.question: Building more highways will not reduce congestion. Which option strengthens this?

options.B: Many commuters avoid driving because highways feel too crowded

questions.solution: If people avoid driving only because roads are crowded, new lanes attract them → confirms argument.

questions.question: What would most weaken the supplement claim?

options.E: Non-exercisers show no benefit from supplement

questions.solution: If supplement doesn’t work for non-exercisers, the supplement isn’t responsible for benefits.

questions.question: Which weakens the green tea stress conclusion?

options.E: Stress can be reduced by many dietary changes

questions.solution: Alternative cause → exercise may lower stress instead.

questions.question: Which strengthens the museum consultant’s argument?

options.C: Visitors would come less often if prices increased

questions.solution: Shows raising prices directly reduces revenue → supports claim.

questions.question: Which weakens the claim that morning workouts increase productivity?
questions.solution: If sleep is the real cause, morning workouts aren’t responsible.

questions.question: Which strengthens the argument against closing the library?

options.E: Residents use free internet to job-search

questions.solution: If closure removes critical job-search resources, reliance on social programs rises → strengthens argument.

questions.question: A researcher claims that remote employees are more productive than office employees. The researcher cites a study showing that remote workers completed more tasks per week.

options.A: Remote workers tend to work in quieter environments.
options.B: The study controlled for job role, experience, and project type.
options.C: Many companies now offer hybrid work arrangements.
options.D: Remote workers take fewer vacation days.
options.E: Office workers often collaborate in person.

questions.solution: Controlling variables strengthens the claim by ruling out alternative explanations.

questions.question: A nutritionist argues that a high-protein diet improves concentration. The claim is based on surveys showing that people who consume high-protein breakfasts report better focus.

options.A: Some survey respondents misreported their protein intake.
options.B: Most respondents also slept more than average.
options.C: People follow different types of diets.
options.D: Protein breakfasts are becoming more popular.

questions.solution: Sleep is a confounding factor that could explain improved focus instead of protein.

questions.question: A city government claims that adding bike lanes will reduce traffic congestion. Which information would be most useful to evaluate this claim?

options.A: Whether the city has plans to expand bus routes.
options.B: How many residents currently commute by bicycle.
options.C: How much the bike lanes will cost to build.
options.D: Whether the city receives federal transportation subsidies.
options.E: How many bike accidents occurred last year.

questions.solution: To reduce traffic, enough residents must realistically switch to biking.

questions.question: A technology startup claims that introducing flexible work hours increased employee retention. Since implementing the policy, annual turnover fell by 20%.

options.A: Most employees rate flexible hours as their favorite benefit.
options.B: Competitor companies did not change their retention rates during the same period.
options.C: The startup also increased salaries the year before.
options.D: The company hired fewer new employees last year.

questions.solution: A comparison group with stable turnover supports the causal link.
